title: 107_hr2558
content:
The Act titled "Teacher Voluntary Early Retirement Incentive Act of 2001" allows for voluntary early retirement incentive plans for governmental and higher education employees. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is amended to allow voluntary retirement incentive plans for employees of educational agencies and institutions of higher education, with age-based reductions in benefits permitted only for supplemental benefits. The Teacher Voluntary Early Retirement Incentive Act of 2001 allows employees to elect to retire with a minimum 180-day opportunity, and prohibits age-based reductions in supplemental benefits. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to determining if a voluntary employee early retirement plan by a local educational agency or institution of higher education violated the Age Discrimination in Employment Act after January 1, 1996. SEC. 3. Retiree medical benefits coordinated with Medicare and other governmental and employer benefit plans; voluntary early retirement incentive plans maintained by local educational agencies. (a) Voluntary Early Retirement Incentive Plans Maintained by Local Educational Agencies.--Section 4(l)(1) of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is amended to include voluntary early retirement plans by local educational agencies coordinating with defined benefit plans.
(b) Retiree Medical Benefits Coordinated With Medicare Benefits.--Section 4(l) of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 is amended to clarify that it is not a violation for an employee benefit plan to coordinate with Medicare benefits. The Employment Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 provides for medical benefits for retired participants, which may be affected if the participant is eligible for medical benefits under the Social Security Act or a state employee benefit plan. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to determine violations of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act for early retirement plans maintained by local educational agencies or employee benefit plans providing medical benefits for retired participants. The curr_chunk states that a defined benefit plan maintained by a local educational agency is considered a defined benefit plan for any purpose, including age discrimination in employment.
